channel.title: Domestic or International Terrorism?
channel.description:
Two explosions have been reported near the Boston Marathon finish line, about three hours after winners finished the race. Crews were sent to the site of the explosions at about 2:30 p.m. According to CNN reports, at least six people were hurt. Witnesses said several victims lost limbs, and the area was being evacuated. The Associated Press reported bloody spectators were being carried to a medical tent set up for fatigued runners. Many of the injured appeared to be spectators who gathered for the 117th running of the race. Local reports stated that the blasts happened across the street from the Lenox Hotel. The victims were being taken to Massachusetts General Hospital.
http://www.cnn.com/2013/04/15/us/boston-marathon-explosions/index.html?hpt=hp_t1 The video's pretty crazy, I'll post if I can find it. So what do you guys think? Domestic? That's what I'm assuming.

item.title: Domestic or International Terrorism?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Cole1497, post:79, topic:516291”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=634551.msg4286768#msg4286768 date=1366471781]
But why does we care so much about this incident? People die everyday.
[/quote]
Ah yes, the old “bad things happen every day, therefor nobody should care” argument. The population of boston is ~625,000. This guy caused almost the entire city to stay indoors for a whole day; schools were closed, people didn’t go to work, the whole thing. His brother shot and killed a cop at the MIT campus (but wait, american cops=pigs to you, why should you care?), and then had almost the entire Boston police force searching for this guy. He was by all means a terrorist, and it’s not entirely often that America has a terrorist attack on it’s own land. Nobody’s lessening the fact that people die every day, because everyone knows people die every day, but this is more than just “people dying”.[/quote]
Do people know how many people the Obama administration kills through the drug laws? No, so stop reporting too much on this, and educate people about the real dangers.

Read full topic

item.title: Domestic or International Terrorism?
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

A girl who visited their home for years said that within the last couple years, their whole family started acting different (they started wearing different types of clothes & her mom talked about the government being behind disasters such as 9-11). She also stated that their family was never really that religious, but within the last few years started to get into it. That was on CNN, so it’s probably wrong anyway.

Read full topic

item.title: Domestic or International Terrorism?
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Apparently its started to point to the older brother now, family members had said he was up to no good and told the younger brother not to listen to him because he was becoming extremist. IIRC he was even kicked out of his house for his extremist views.

Read full topic

item.title: Domestic or International Terrorism?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

rip4d:

Its because a lot of us are considering it the first “major” act of terrorism since 9/11. Honestly, while I do think this was a terrible thing, we take the concept of bombing way out of hand, along with whatever violent acts occur. The media just focuses on every little bad thing that happens and shares it with the world, which is retarded. News should focus on good things and major events, not having every story be about a murder in New York.

First in US since 9/11.

Read full topic

item.title: Domestic or International Terrorism?
item.dc:creator: @Teem_Rocket Teem_Rocket
item.description:
@Teem_Rocket wrote:

[quote=“JavaTC, post:58, topic:516291”][quote author=Teem_Rocket link=topic=634551.msg4283892#msg4283892 date=1366080182]

Cant imagine how much that hurts

I doubt there was very much pain involved at first, odds are he went into shock almost immediately. He probably didn’t feel much of anything after the initial severing of his leg. I’m positive that it was absolutely unbearable pain when it occurred though. Once the shock and adrenaline wear off, however, he will be in a massive amount of excruciating physical and mental pain. I say mental as well, because there’s a very large amount of mental trauma involved with losing a limb, especially when It’s violently. I’ve heard that It’s a very strange feeling, because even though the limb is severed, it still feels as if it were there for weeks afterwards…
[/quote]
Pretty sure that’s because of how the human brain works since I went on a cruise for a week and when I got home for an entire day I could still feel the rocking of the ship.

OT: That picture made me sad[/quote]

Another similar example, is when you’ve been driving a car for a day or so. If you sit still, your vision is strange and acts as if you’re still moving forward in the car, when you aren’t.

Read full topic
